pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->
I want to define a nucleus. [nlab](https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/nucleus). This is only a draft and I would be happy to get some feedback if this is a sensible definition. Is it correct to put it into a new file or is there a more suitable place for it?

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: messageFile.md
Do you plan to prove some nontrivial theorem that involves nuclei, or just add a definition?

A first step would be to prove, that the Nuclei form a Frame. We are currently trying to understand and formalize this paper [arxiv](https://arxiv.org/abs/1303.5631) about topos theoretic measure theory.
messageFile.md
messageFile.md

> messageFile.md

What does this mean mister Action bot?
See https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/messageFile.2Emd
messageFile.md
messageFile.md

> Can you define the obvious map `Nucleus.toClosureOperator` and derive your results using it?

I defined the map, but I have no idea how I can make my results cleaner by using this map. Are there any examples that I could look at to understand this?
messageFile.md

> I defined the map, but I have no idea how I can make my results cleaner by using this map. Are there any examples that I could look at to understand this?

Eg to deduce that a nucleus `f` is monotone you can do `example (f : Nucleus X) : Monotone f := f.toClosureOperator.monotone`
messageFile.md
messageFile.md

> See https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/messageFile.2Emd

Per the above, can you please merge master?
Ohh, of course, I read that the wrong way

### PR summary [61772c379a](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19440/commits/61772c379a9ffc0df6f242d2f7784e5228649084)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Order.Nucleus` (new file)|275|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Nucleus`
`+ NucleusClass`
`+ bot_apply`
`+ coe_bot`
`+ coe_le_coe`
`+ coe_lt_coe`
`+ coe_toInfHom`
`+ coe_top`
`+ ext`
`+ idempotent`
`+ instBot`
`+ instTop`
`+ instance : BoundedOrder (Nucleus X)`
`+ instance : FunLike (Nucleus X) X X`
`+ instance : NucleusClass (Nucleus X) X`
`+ instance : PartialOrder (Nucleus X) := .lift (⇑) DFunLike.coe_injective`
`+ instance : TopHomClass (Nucleus X) X X`
`+ le_apply`
`+ map_inf`
`+ toClosureOperator`
`+ toFun_eq_coe`
`+ top_apply`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
oops, git was telling me something about unrelated histories and now there are 93 files changed... I'll just reopen the pull request if I don't manage to fix this here
Wait a second, I can fix that quickly for you
Please make sure your local `Nucleus` branch has **no changes you care about**, then run `git reset --hard origin/Nucleus` on that branch. ⚠️ **This will lose any local changes on that branch** ⚠️

I'm sorry, I hadn't read your message before pushing, I just deleted all the files that were added by the merge. Now everything seems to be fine. But  thank a lot you for your effort so late in the evening! Just out of interest, what was the quick fix that you did locally?
I did `git fetch; git rebase origin/master; git push --force`, which redid all your commits above current master, except the one that added 33K lines to the diff
Thanks again for your fix, are there any more changes to the PR that you would suggest?
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

> Thanks!
> 
> maintainer delegate

Thank you for your patience, I certainly learned a lot during this PR :smile:

Thanks!

maintainer delegate
I think the location is fine You might to put `Nucleus` in the `Order` namespace to avoid ambiguity. Otherwise, it looks like a sensible definition.
Can you define the obvious map `Nucleus.toClosureOperator` and derive your results using it?
It would be good to expand the module doc a bit. Reading it doesn't really make me feel like I've learned anything

Thanks!

maintainer delegate

Bundled morphisms in Mathlib should come with `FunLike` instance, and possibly with `NucleusClass`. See any other bundled morphism (e.g., `InfHom` which you may want to extend) for an example.

Also, you should define at least `Nucleus.id`. Probably, also a definition for the constant function sending everything to `\top`.

This should become an instance
```
instance [NucleusClass F X] : OrderHomClass F X X
```
Please only assume `toFun (toFun x) ≤ toFun x` here.
Do you need `Order.Frame` here? Why not just `SemilatticeInf`?
What about the lemmas where I need other Frame properties (like \top and suprema)? Should I require these properties just for these lemmas?
Can you expand this docstring to say what a nucleus is?

Does "The Type of Nuclei on a Frame. A Nucleus is a function between Frames which corresponds to a
sublocle. It is idempotent, increasing and preserves infima." suffice?
I think it's fine to drop the first sentence
Can you `extends InfHomClass` instead of having `preserves_inf`?
Then you don't need this instance
simp proofs are quite robust and usually fast, so I would say make them simp

Pro-tip: you can do
```suggestion
  top.toFun := ⊤
  top.idempotent := by simp
  -- ...
```
Thank you, I did not know about this
Can you add a "do not use" warning similar to the other bundled homs?

Sorry, I do not quite understand what you mean by this. I tried looking for an example, but I did not find such a warning (for example at FrameHom). What is the reason for not using the Nucleus structure?

If you grep for "do not use" in mathlib, you'll see plenty of example for what I mean.

The reason is that we don't want people to use `Nucleus.toFun` when there is the coercion coming from `FunLike`.
Ok, I understand, I looked at the example at Group.AddChar. But why is there no such warning at [InfHom](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Hom/Lattice.html#InfHom)?

> why is there no such warning at [InfHom](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Hom/Lattice.html#InfHom)?

Oversight. Feel free to open a PR to add such a warning
Ohh ok, if InfHom had this warning it might be smart to just extend InfHom with Nucleus, right?
Similarly, all those fields should be primed and warned against

We prefer the most concrete definition first
```suggestion
/-- A nucleus is an inflationary idempotent `inf`-preserving endomorphism of a semilattice.

In a frame, nuclei correspond to sublocales. -/ -- TODO: Formalise that claim
```

I don't think that docstring brings any value since `Nucleus.idempotent'` is an implementation detail
```suggestion
```

```suggestion
/-- `NucleusClass F X` states that F is a type of nuclei. -/
```
Can you move this to just after the def of `Nucleus`?
Then from here onwards you can be in `namespace Nucleus` to avoid repeating it in declaration names

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma map_top (n : Nucleus X) : n ⊤ = ⊤ :=
```

Leider kein Deutsch :(
```suggestion
/-- `NucleusClass F X` states that F is a type of nuclei. -/
```
Hoppla, daran bin ich wohl zu sehr gewöhnt....

```suggestion
  /-- A nucleus is idempotent. -/
```

```suggestion
  /-- A nucleus is increasing. -/
```

```suggestion
  coe := toFun
```
This does not compile, I believe this is because Nucleus extends InfHom

```suggestion
  coe_injective' f g h := by cases f; congr
```
or maybe
```suggestion
  coe_injective' f g h := by cases f; congr!
```
This is also not compiling, but exact? solved it after congr!.

Ah, then
```suggestion
  coe_injective' f g h := by obtain ⟨⟨_, _⟩, _⟩ := f; congr!
```
should work

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma toFun_eq_coe (n : Nucleus X) : n.toFun = n := rfl
```

```suggestion
  idempotent _ _ := idempotent' ..
  increasing _ _ := increasing' ..
  map_inf _ _ _ := map_inf' ..
```

I might drop this docstring entirely
```suggestion
```

```suggestion
@[ext] lemma ext {m n : Nucleus X} (h : ∀ a, m a = n a) : m = n :=
```
Can you give an instance of `TopHomClass` instead?

```suggestion
  le x y := ⇑x≤ y
```

```suggestion
instance : Preorder (Nucleus X) := .lift (⇑) _ _
```
Are we using different versions here? Because this also doesn't work for me....
Wait, removing the underscores fixes it...

```suggestion
instance instBot : Bot (Nucleus X) where
```

```suggestion

/-- The biggest Nucleus sends everything to ⊤. -/
instance top : Top (Nucleus X) where
  top.toFun := ⊤
  top.idempotent' := by simp
  top.increasing' := by simp
  top.map_inf' := by simp

@[simp, norm_cast] lemma coe_bot : ⇑(⊥ : Nucleus X) = id := rfl
@[simp, norm_cast] lemma coe_top : ⇑(⊤ : Nucleus X) = ⊤ := rfl

@[simp] lemma bot_apply (x : X) : (⊥ : Nucleus X) x = x := rfl
@[simp] lemma top_apply (x : X) : (⊤ : Nucleus X) x = ⊤ := rfl

```

```suggestion
  bot_le n := increasing n
```

```suggestion
  le_top _ _ := by simp
```

```suggestion

  Do not use this directly. Instead use `NucleusClass.idempotent`. -/
```

```suggestion

  Do not use this directly. Instead use `NucleusClass.increasing`. -/
```

```suggestion
lemma le_apply : x ≤ n x :=
```

```suggestion
  le_apply (x : X) (f : F) : x ≤ f x
```

```suggestion
  le_apply' (x : X) : x ≤ toFun x
```

```suggestion
instance : Preorder (Nucleus X) := .lift (⇑)

@[simp, norm_cast] lemma coe_le_coe : ⇑m ≤ n ↔ m ≤ n := .rfl
@[simp, norm_cast] lemma coe_lt_coe : ⇑m < n ↔ m < n := .rfl

```

```suggestion
lemma toFun_eq_coe (n : Nucleus X) : n.toFun = n := rfl
@[simp] lemma coe_toInfHom (n : Nucleus X) : ⇑n.toInfHom = n := rfl
```

```suggestion

Locales are the dual concept to frames. A nucleus is an endomorphism of a frame
which corresponds to a sublocale.

## References

https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/nucleus
```

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Order.Closure
import Mathlib.Order.CompleteLattice
import Mathlib.Order.Hom.Lattice
```

```suggestion
instance : BoundedOrder (Nucleus X) where
  bot_le _ _ := le_apply
  le_top _ _ := by simp
```

```suggestion
instance : PartialOrder (Nucleus X) := .lift (⇑) DFunLike.coe_injective
```

```suggestion
/-- The biggest `Nucleus` sends everything to `⊤`. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- The smallest `Nucleus` is the identity. -/
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Order/Nucleus): Nucleus
